prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CO(1-0) * 3x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the CO(1-0) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 22"). The derived flux is 600 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 5%, we determine a peak flux density of ~120 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~30 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission in only 8 minutes on source.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

We have set up the spw, which targets the line, in FDM mode with 3840 channels (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s). This setup is necessary, since the emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, we cannot avoid using the selected setup.

CO(1-0) is expected to show up in bright knots, but it is also expected to show up on larger scales. For our analysis of the circumnuclear disk, it is sufficient to trace CO up to scales of the disk (~30").

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_13CO_C18O
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * 13CO(1-0) * C18O(1-0) * CS(2-1) * 1x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the 13CO(1-0) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 22"). The derived flux is 60 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 5%, we determine a peak flux density of ~12 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.

The largest angular scale of the 13CO emission is expected to be of the same order as the 12CO (~30"; targeted in Science Goal "B3_CO"), but in this science goal we aim for the position-dependent line ratio of 13CO/12CO in bright knots on small scales < 7 ".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3_HNC_HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HNC(1-0) * HCN(1-0) * HCO+(1-0) * 1x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HNC(1-0) and HCN(1-0) lines. We estimate the peak flux densities from Single Dish observations (beam size: 57"). The derived fluxes are 130 and 250 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 1% (due to the large beam size), we determine a peak flux density of ~20 and ~38 mJy/beam, which allows us to detect the line with a SNR > 8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.
HNC and HCN are expected to show up in bright knots within the circumnuclear disk. Therefore, it is sufficient to trace angular scales of < 7".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6_HCN

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HCN(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 12"). The derived flux is 56 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 10%, we determine a peak flux density of ~19 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 1000 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.
HCN is expected to show up in bright knots within the circumnuclear disk. Therefore, it is sufficient to trace angular scales of < 7".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6_HNC
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HNC(3-2) * 3x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HNC(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 12"). The derived flux is 34 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 10%, we determine a peak flux density of ~12 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.
HNC is expected to show up in bright knots within the circumnuclear disk. Therefore, it is sufficient to trace angular scales of < 7".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * CO(3-2) * HCO+(4-3) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the CO(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The derived flux is 680 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 10%, we determine a peak flux density of ~180 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~25 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 700 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.

CO(3-2) is expected to show up in bright knots, but it is also expected to show up on larger scales. For our analysis of the circumnuclear disk, it is sufficient to trace CO up to scales of the disk (~30").

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_13CO_C18O
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * 13CO(3-2) * C18O(3-2) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the 13CO(3-2) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The measured flux is 80 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 10%, we determine a peak flux density of ~20 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 700 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.

The largest angular scale of the 13CO emission is expected to be of the same order as the 12CO (~30"; targeted in Science Goal "B7_CO"), but in this science goal we aim for the position-dependent line ratio of 13CO/12CO in bright knots on small scales < 7 ".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7_HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal targets: * HCN(4-3) * HCO+(4-3) * 2x continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This Science Goal targets the HCN(4-3) line. We estimate the peak flux density from Single Dish observations (beam size: 14"). The derived flux is 62 Jy km/s. Assuming an overall linewidth of 200 km/s, and a filling factor of 10%, we determine a peak flux density of ~16 mJy in a 1" beam. That allows us to detect the line with a SNR of ~8 in a 5 km/s channel to resolve individual knots of emission.
The continuum emission of the circumnuclear disk is expected to be around 100 mJy, the nucleus itself is a point source with ~5 Jy. We are aware of the nucleus' impact, and its limitation to the continuum dynamic range.

The emission of Cen A exhibits linewidths of a few hundred kilometers, but towards the nucleus it shows extremely narrow absorption features with FWHM < 1 km/s in all the targeted lines of this Science Goal. Since our aim is to determine the full line structure, spectral averaging is not an option.

The datarate exceeds the data rate policy value, because the spectral windows that target lines are set up with 3840 channels each (bandwidth > 700 km/s, resolution < 1 km/s) for the reasons that we have given in the justification of the correlator configuration.
HCN is expected to show up in bright knots within the circumnuclear disk. Therefore, it is sufficient to trace angular scales of < 7".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We will use ALMA to obtain detailed images of the circumnuclear disk in the nearest giant radio galaxy, Centaurus A, in a selected number of molecular transitions. The set is designed to enable a comprehensive study of the physical condition and kinematical structure of its circumnuclear disk (CND). As the gas reservoir fuelling both a supermassive black hole (SMBH) and a massive outflow, the CND is the key to understanding the evolution of the radio galaxy core. Cen A is the only radio galaxy in which the CND can be studied in detail; all others are too distant.
In the Cen A core, (i) the SMBH is surrounded by (ii) a cool CND from which matter falls in towards (iii) a 90 pc hot inner zone where much of it is deflected into (iv) a massive outflow of gas at modest speeds along the much faster jets emanating from the SMBH. With ALMA we will map the CND, hot contact zone, and the outflow region at a resolution of 20 pc (1") in order to determine the detailed spatial distribution of gas motion, density, mass, and temperature in the close vicinity of an actively accreting nuclear black hole, using the radiative transfer models developed specifically for such purposes.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: The nature of the massive gas outflow from Centaurus A

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
